definition: the ability to acquire and apply knowledge and skills
Alan Turing
term: who is commonly associated with the genesis of the idea of artificial intelligence?

definition: John McCarthy in 1955
term: who coined the term "artificial intelligence" and when?

definition: 1950, a test developed by Alan Turing (a british computer scientist) to determine whether or not a computer is "intelligent"
some argued that the Turing test is not a true test of intelligence, Searle's Chinese Room thought experiment
term: what experiment tried to refute Turing's ideas?

definition: two people, hidden from a third, third person asks questions to determine which one is male and female, one person lies and the other tells the truth
what is one player was a computer? could the computer convince the human player that it was a human as well?
term: How did Turing propose a slight twist to the Imitation Game with respect from AI?

definition: artificial narrow intelligence (weak ai), artificial general intelligence (strong ai), artificial superintelligence
IBM's deep blue, spam filters, Google's AlphaGo, microsoft's tay, apple's siri, a.l.i.c.e, google cars
term: examples of artificial narrow intelligence (weak ai)

definition: recursive self improvement, 'the singularity', relatively good in more than one field, IBM's Watson
term: examples of artificial general intelligence (strong ai)

definition: an intelligence that's smarter than a human in every field

1. increase computational power
2. make it "smart"-try to have it emulate the brain and have it do thinking on its own
term: two ways to get to strong ai (AGI)

definition: pretty much the same thing as we do to get from ani to agi do we want to do this?!
term: how do we get from agi to asi?

definition: could be benevolent and solve all our problems like cancer, aging, and anything else
it could perceive us as a threat or insignificant and could lead us to our extinction
a thought experiment in ethics (1. do nothing and 5 people die, 2. pull the lever and one person dies)
term: trolley problem (example of how to teach morality to ai)

definition: rule based algorithms, tree based algorithms, genetic algorithms, neural algorithms
